content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												There are so many versions of Worms out there but the original is the one with---*Less cartoony graphics - pixel art here instead of smooth cartoons.*Fewer items - you have a good selection of weapons, but the most exotic items are the exploding sheep and banana bomb - no Holy Hand Grenade, Carpet Bomb or jet pack in this version.*Less polish - sound effects are fuzzy and the menus are a bit unwieldy.*Worse AI - computer characters never use ropes, spam the teleport awkwardly, get stuck behind cover and never ever miss with ranged weapons.But--Some (me) would say that the original game is superior to 'Worms 2' and every edition since then, most of which are esentially inferior clones or inconsequential tweaks to the sequel. The original is special. Its dated look and feel have aged respectably rather than stagnated (the bright coloured candy canes and bug eyes of Worms 2 look a bit naff today wheras the detailed, carefully-drawn objects here still look wonderful - see the Satan statues straight out of Shadow of the Beast).The smaller selection of weapons make the game more strategic and engaging, allowing it to retain an element of skill and a rising tension. And this version alone retains a great sense of fun and exploration that the many rehashes seem to replace with cynicism.Only in the original 'Worms' will you find a huge collection of gorgeous, hand-drawn custom stages that smash into pixels when you play on them, or a lovely, extremely 90's full-length re-mix of the theme tune hidden in the options menus. And only here will your worms shout 'suck on this' in a silly voice before shooting a pair of 'wanted criminals' named Robson and Jerome in the face with an uzi. With their last ounce of strength. On the Statue of Liberty. With a worm's face on it. This version has heart!

content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
												Come on, Worms surely needs no introduction, right? If you aren't familiar with this game, you're either too young to have had the pleasure of playing it or simply unfortunate enough to never get around to it. Truly a masterpiece of a game for it's time, this is the game that put Team 17 on the map and strengthened their reputation as a company. Despite it's revolutionary past, Worms hasn't really stood well against the test of time, it hasn't aged very well at all, unlike it's sequel series of games  (Worms 2, Worms Armageddon, Worms World Party) which are timeless and still loads of fun to play to this day. I'd still recommend picking up the original Worms for the nostalgia value, despite DosBox being a nightmare to work with on modern machines. If you are new to the series however, I would advise picking up Worms Armageddon instead, it is vastly superior and has been updated over the course of time to compensate for modern computers.

Originally posted by Boggy B:Spadge? NOOOOOO!!!This game doesn't have excellent graphics. It doesn't have quicktime events, nor does it allow you to dodge incoming fire. You can't level up your character, and there are no respawn points.So what does it have? Silly accents. Silly accents, and a great deal of heart. Silly accents, and exploding sheep. Silly accents, and that mounting dread when, one by one, your squad is picked off by unerring robotic assailants. Silly accents and the triumphant swell of pride when, finally, the last of those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s is in your sights, and you are a squeeze of the trigger away from avenging your fallen comrades. Mostly though, it's the silly accents.Buy this game - there are silly accents.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												This is how this legendary series started. In 2016, after SO MANY YEARS, this game isn't probably best choice for session with friends. I mean, people loved Worms Armageddon, Worms World Party is my favorite Worms games, new players are probably in love with Worms Reloaded or Revolutions. First Worms game can be only played out of curiousity, how this all started. Older players for sure love first Worms and play it once in a while but nobody else will spend days playing it. It was my first time in two years (and first time on Steam) since I played Worms. Didn't spend much time but had my dose of nostalgia. Team17 had great idea for game and even with using same scheme in every next game (except spin-offs) they are making every next Worms game better and more fun. Old Worms works fine on modern computers and, at least in my case, didn't had any trouble running and playing it.Thank you Team17 for starting such a great series, (almost) never dissapointing. For many this game is priceless but if you ever played any Worms game and want to see how it all started, grab it at some sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
												I first played this on the Sega Saturn several years ago. Already familiar with its immediate (and infinitely more refined) sequels, Worms 2 and Armageddon, I was mostly unimpressed. I revisited it on Steam with the assumption that I’d half-heartedly play a game or two, exit to desktop and write up a review labelling it “Not Recommended,” partly because it’s been made obsolete by newer instalments and partly because it just wasn’t much fun to begin with. Not quite. Whether it’s because the Steam version is more enhanced than the Saturn port, or simply because of something I missed the first time round, I find that there’s much more entertainment to be had with the original Worms than I remembered. I expected a barely-functioning prototype to the classic Worms formula presented in Worms 2 and perfected in Worms Armageddon, but in reality it’s a solid turn-based strategy that holds up surprisingly well and, just as importantly, manages to retain its own unique flavour, distinct from any of the titles that followed it. For a 20-year-old game running on a slightly shaky version of DosBox*, it looks and sounds fantastic. There’s a lot of detail in each themed environment, every inch of which can be destroyed by the usual high-impact weapons you’d expect to find in a Worms title. It’s an impressive achievement for 1995, and one that has obvious implications on gameplay. The worms themselves look a little worse, 8-bit sprites against a backdrop that appears to have evolved without them, yet there’s a certain something in their choppy animations that, in addition to slightly awkward but otherwise well-meaning FMV clips, lends to the overall light-hearted, cartoon feel of the game. That, and a wide variety of voice banks that see your team speaking in anything from hyperactive American to thick Norwegian. The gameplay itself will be familiar to anyone who’s ever played a Worms game - take turns navigating purposefully cumbersome worms across a dangerous terrain, utilising increasingly dangerous weaponry to, you know, destroy all enemies - and in this original release it works remarkably well. Some gameplay tweaks from future instalments are missing here - once you begin to fire a bazooka, for instance, you cannot change its trajectory at the last minute. Inconsistencies in the A.I. are also present - at times, computer-controlled worms freeze for the duration of their turn; other times, they fire missiles and throw grenades with accuracy that guarantees a perfect hit. Worms has always been best enjoyed with other people, however, and that doesn’t change here. This is not the best Worms game - in fact, it may well be the weakest of the original 2D titles. But as the precursor to one of the best (if a little tired) multiplayer series ever devised, it’s well worth giving a shot, no matter how familiar you are with other instalments. And if you can allow for its flaws, there’s a good chance you’ll find yourself sticking with the original Worms for more than one round. *There are some hoops to jump through in getting Worms to run on Windows 8.1, and probably a bunch of other operating systems. Fortunately the solution is mostly straightforward, and can be found in Steam's community hub.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
This game requires DOSBOX, sounds like a rip-off of money, eh? But I still buy it because it's classic, that's all. I bought the whole collection on Steam long time ago, this Worms is not an inferior version comparing to its sequels.In retrospect, it perfectly illustrates what exactly is masterpiece. Having been playing Worms series for at least 15 years, they never make me feel jaded however. Instead, I still play it on my phone, pad, and Xbox. About this oldest pixel Worms, my advice is, if you are not familiar with DOSBOX or, not from DOS era, don't play this, grow some pubes first and play other Worms instead, because they are pretty famous on mobile platfrom, lots of young people know its siblings like Reloaded from Symbian as well, you can easily get used to the control.Many people dislike pixel games because modern games have greatly advanced graphics, but most of modern games are just for fastfood culture, in another word, one-offs. Worms are not disposable, you will immediately enjoy it, and the delights will endure in your heart for a long time.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pieDirections:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

number of helpful: 0 of 9 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												trying to calculate how far or high a weapon flies and apply wind speed and direction is WAY more difficult here than worms armageddon, land mines are practically invisible, in challenge mode you'll come across a completely ASININE mission that cannot be conquered! it's basically just a level where you can send your worms to their doom as they get obliterated into non-existance one hit at a time, no matter where on the map they are, even if you're deep underground. all you can really use is a bazooka and that's IF you can hit them at all. here's the password for the satanic unwinnable mission 15, "good bye" ( pager call for the grim reaper there ) apply the space between good and bye. over all, this game is WAY tougher than it looks, not meant for kids because they are not ready to play a game this intense. you need precision, patience and high gaming skill to hit tiny targets with tiny weapons, it's too much like playing golf then going to war, especially when nearly every weapon is taken away from you when you play challenge mode, what else can you do? oh yeah, did i forget to mention that the unwinnable level doesn't let you have any ammunition but a bazooka to fight back with?! i have to say the only thing about this game i really like is the animated cutscenes before the start of a match. one of the evil games of 95, i wouldn't recommend this game unless you were something else.

number of helpful: 3 of 21 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 4, 2012
												Worms is a 2D 90s game where you play as a worm that can lob all sorts of artillery power against all of your worm enemies. Other than playing this game for nostalgia reason, there is no other reason for anyone to be playing this. Worms reloaded is available on steam and is infinitely better. If you are looking for some good old classic games, was too young to know about worms in ‘95, or was living under a rock in ’95 and didn’t get a chance to play this then have a go at this game in the 21st century. Multiplayer is local so you can still have some fun with some friends. Overall I would recommend against getting this game. Like yearly sports game, why would you play the older product?

content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												This game is a classic for any worms fan, but:- Too bad there isn't an offline singleplayer mode. - It has an average offline 2 player. I think there are better worms games out there.   => Worms armageddon has a better graphical quality, for instance. - This game runs on DOSbox.- The cutscenes before starting a game, are very bad and even have lags in them.Only buy this game if you are a fan of the worms series, or when you want to relive/play classic pc games. Otherwise I advice you to stay away from this game OR buy another (better) game of the worms series.Thank you for reading & feel free to check out my other reviews.

												If you expect Worms 1 from Amiga - dont buy it.If you expect Worms 1 with much worse graphic, just old PC version for DOS - buy it (if you think it really worthwhile to buy for that price).I remember Amiga version, with nice graphic, this isnt my game. Differences?PC version have pixelz - Amiga version have nice graphics with styleSounds on PC version are terrible.There is no problem with HD space today but why this game required ~321MB?They should sell original/unmodified copies from Amiga, ported, not strange crappy♥♥♥♥♥♥(check out SuperFrog HD).Anyway, it's still a good old game - this version just ruin my memories.You should better buy Armageddon - it's good old-new game too. Reloaded - good version, just like Worms World Party, or Revolution - newest Worms, 2D with very nice graphics.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
												The original and in my opinion the best. Probably too expensive for a 20-year-old game, but if you haven't played it before you ought to. Weapons were not overpowered like they are now, making for an interesting and balanced strategy game. Worms were more sarcastic and amusing than in the sequels. The maps were more varied, with reduced friction ice maps and reduced gravity Mars maps mixing things up.The only negative is that the multiplayer option is limited to have several players playing on the same computer - there is no internet/LAN option. If they "modernized" it with including internet play, which I'm sure would be possible now, there would be no fault in the game at all.The game is loaded through DosBox automatically, so should be compatible with the majority of machines - it runs fine in Windows 8.1 for me.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Worms is a one (up to four) player, turn based 2D artillery game about the namesake worms shooting, bombing and blasting the humbug out of each other. It's old. It's pixelated. It's a bit slow in gameplay compared to later titles in the series.Still, the fully destructible terrains, the crude humor and the music combine nicely with the tactical gameplay.Can I recommend worms? If you like old games or are already a fan of the series, sure, go ahead (you might want to look for the worms collection bundle though). If you've never played a part of the series before, better get worms armageddon or one of the later titles instead.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												Worms is a staple franchise of the Team 17 company. It's a turn based game where the main opponents are worms who try to kill each other with an assortment of weapons to choose from. The last remaining worm who isn't killed makes the team a victor. Each level has a different challenge depending on the layout of the levels and the condition of the wind blowing in the air which affects the projectile of the weapons' ammo. The stradegy of the Worms game helped made itself a memorible title which has since been ported to other consoles and spawned a vast selection of remakes and sequals. If you want to play the game that started it all, then look no further as this is the original itself.
